title: American College of Parliamentary Lawyers
text:
The American College of Parliamentary Lawyers (ACPL) is a <a href="professional%20association">professional association</a> of lawyers from the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and <a href="Canada">Canada</a>.
Founded in 2007, the College states that one of its purposes is "to provide a forum for the exchange of information among experienced legal professionals for the purpose of the advancement of parliamentary law". This organization also advocates the use of <a href="parliamentary%20procedure">parliamentary procedure</a> in <a href="Voluntary%20association">voluntary organizations</a>.
"Parliamentary law" (i.e. the procedures used by <a href="Deliberative%20assembly">deliberative assemblies</a> to make decisions in <a href="Meeting%20%28parliamentary%20procedure%29">meetings</a>) is separate from the <a href="Law">legal</a> matters that lawyers are trained in. Generally, lawyers are not necessarily also <a href="Parliamentarian%20%28consultant%29">parliamentarians</a>, or experts in meeting procedures. As a result, this association was formed to connect the two fields. Only individuals who are both lawyers and parliamentarians could be members in this organization.
For its meetings, ACPL uses <a href="Robert%27s%20Rules%20of%20Order">Robert's Rules of Order</a> Newly Revised (RONR) to conduct its business.
